results.title: Beyond kicks
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about a group of young volunteers, the Free Youth Clinic, who run a ‘crisis bus’ to rescue young people experiencing bad drug trips, usually LSD. They pull up whenever the need arises and try to talk the person down. If the patient needs further medical aid, they know where to obtain it. The film shows some of the patients being interviewed after their rescue.

results.title: Beyond Everest (1980). Beyond Everest: the ongoing climb of Sherpa Hillary (2000)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dillon, Dick Smith Adventure and Michael Dillon Film Enterprises
results.brief_description: Conquering the mountain of Everest was not Sir Edmund Hillary’s only achievement in Nepal. Through a philanthropic enterprise he continued to fund development projects for the Nepalese people - projects that the people themselves requested. His legacy will live on through the children of Nepal attending one of the some 30 schools that his “Himalayan Trust” built since 1961 - in many cases by his own hands. This DVD contains two documentaries - one made in 1980 is about Sir Edmund at sixty years of age and the other made in 2000 continues the subject matter of his philanthropic work - the DVD release commemorates the 50th Anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary’s ascent of Mount Everest.

results.title: Between two wars: sunshine and eclipse (1927-1934)
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Confident, prosperous Canada, expanding in all directions; then the stock market crash of 1929, its sequel the Great Depression, and a nation staggering with poverty and unemployment. But with it all, an optimistic outlook: bargains by mail order; extremes in women’s fashions; political see-sawing; hockey broadcasts by a very youthful Foster Hewitt; the word “quintuplets” in every headline.

results.title: Beyond the clouds = Par-dela les nuages
results.creator_credit: Michelangelo Antonioni, Philippe Carcassonne, Stephen Tchal Gadjieff, Cecchi Gori Group, Cine B, France 3 Cinema, Road Movies Zweite Produktionen and Sunshine
results.brief_description: This was Antonioni’s return to filmmaking after suffering a stroke in 1985. He presents 4 vignettes linked thematically by notions of desire, as well as a fictional director in search of a story (portrayed by John Malkovich). In the first story two beautiful lovers, Silvano and Carmen (Kim Rossi Stuart and Ines Sastre) are unable to consummate their love because of his pursuit of perfection. In the second story John Malkovich’s character meets a woman (Sophie Marceau) who confesses to killing her father. The third story involves a man (Peter Weller) who must decide between his wife (Fanny Ardant) and his lover (Chiara Caselli). In the final story a man (Vincent Perez) becomes obsessed with a woman (Irene Jacob) who is “satisfied” with life and is about to enter a convent. Screen legends Jeanne Moreau and Marcello Mastroianni make a brief appearance and have an overall involvement to the story rather than being directly involved with any of the vignettes. In French, Italian and English with English subtitles. Co-directed by Wim Wenders.

results.title: Beyond the blue meanies: the animation of Paul Driessen
results.creator_credit: Paul Driessen and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: After working on the Beatles’ animated film “Yellow submarine” Paul Driessen immigrated to Canada and joined the National Film Board in 1972. The six films in this compilation showcase the whimsical and unique style of a renowned prize-winning animator. Contains: “Le Bleu perdu/The Lost blue” : Grey smog clouds the earth and a young boy dons a pair of wings to learn that there is a clear blue sky; “Air!”: Clean, fresh air is becoming scarce as plants, birds, fish and finally, people, come to the same “breathless” end; “Cat’s cradle”: A parable using the metaphor of the cat’s cradle shows that all our lives are interconnected; “An old box”: During Christmas a lonely homeless man finds a magical box that takes him on a fantastic spiritual journey; “The Same old story”: Life is stranger than fiction — a truism that comes alive in this deceptively simple film; “The End of the world in four seasons”: Eight stories unfold simultaneously on screen in this witty black comedy to the accompaniment of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons.

results.title: Beyond reasonable doubt: the Leith Rattan case
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Murray Travis and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Leith Rattan was found guilty of murdering his wife Beverly in their Echuca home and sentenced to death by hanging in a Shepparton Court. However, the verdict took many people by surprise and the sentence was later commuted to 25 years in prison. Rattan had always staunchly maintained that the shooting was an accident, although the police investigation seemingly identified a motive and opportunity. There were four appeals to higher courts on the grounds of the prosecution’s evidence and the original judgment made, however they were all dismissed. Through dramatised re-enactment and a thorough explanation of the forensic evidence offered at the original trial, presenter Gordon Hawkins casts doubt over the veracity of the evidence presented by the prosecution and asks was Rattan’s guilt proven beyond reasonable doubt? He also makes the point that the trial process itself is fraught with inequities and can often affect the accused person’s chance of a fair trial.

results.title: Beyond El Rocco
results.creator_credit: Kevin Lucas, AFFC and Lucas Produkzions
results.brief_description: ‘Beyond El Rocco’ is an affectionate look at the Australian jazz scene and its evolution through the decades from the swinging 60s through to the experimentalism of the 80s. Tony Barry plays Zoot Finster, a diehard jazz fan who takes us on a personal journey which begins at the El Rocco jazz club in Sydney in the fifties. The film looks not only at the Sydney scene, but brings in developments in Melbourne, including footage of Jazz Centre 44 which was the Melbourne counterpoint to the El Rocco in the fifties. Includes interviews and recordings of sessions with the big names of Australian jazz including Judie Bailey, John Sangster, Don Burrows, Joe Lane, Brian Brown, Bernie McGann, Mike Nock, Roger Frampton, John Pochee, Dale Barlow, Sandy Evans, James Morrison and Paul Grabowski. A must see for jazz fans.

results.title: Beyond Babel. Program 4. Future
results.creator_credit: Mike Fiddler, Ron Blythe, Sally Westbury and Infonation
results.brief_description: With the advent of the 21st century came the unstoppable global spread of English as the universal language. “Beyond Babel” explores the reasons behind this phenomenal growth through four separate programs: Trade, Culture, Politics, Future. This final program studies the future, and the question is put, “What place does English have in our globalised world?”. The twentieth century proved to be the greatest scientific and technological period in recorded history and English was seen as the global language medium of expression for the development and acquisition of this knowledge. Through computers and eventually the internet, the spread of the English language globally grew to about 70%-80%, although this figure is beginning to turn around as more and more non-English speaking countries are accessing the net. There is of course the great divide between the wealthy nations and those that cannot access the internet due to poverty and lack of technological development such as South Africa’s shanty towns and rural village communities. Discusses India’s current situation where many of their brightest IT graduates are being lost to foreign companies. The future it would seem has to be multilingual. Today the BBC broadcasts in 43 languages and CNN are now producing regional language services parallel with the international global English services. Asia as a whole is using English as a second language but still wants to retain each country’s individual identity. Wales has adopted a bi-lingual society with both Welsh and English being taught in schools and South Africa runs both multi-racial and multilingual programs on television. “Beyond Babel” is an excellent documentary, informative, comprehensive and thought provoking. Narrated by Hugh Quarshie.

results.title: Beyond Babel. Program 3. Politics
results.creator_credit: Mike Fiddler, Ron Blythe, Sally Westbury and Infonation
results.brief_description: With the advent of the 21st century came the unstoppable global spread of English as the universal language. “Beyond Babel” explores the reasons behind this phenomenal growth through four separate programs: Trade, Culture, Politics, Future. In this third program the role of English is examined as a medium for international political and diplomatic discourse. Television news via satellite has created a global connection with English as the linking language. America’s CNN was the first global television broadcaster and it was their philosophy (initiated by Ted Turner), to de-Americanise the language to appeal to an international audience. Discusses British colonization of America, followed by the mainly non-English speaking immigrants who formed linguistic ghettos in New York, to today where there has been a dramatic increase in Hispanic immigrants speaking mainly Spanish. A reactionary organization known as “US English” with the slogan “English must be our official language” is gathering in strength to an extent where there are 25 American States who have passed “English only” legislation. Comment is also made about the demise of the Native Americans whose culture and language was deliberately destroyed by white Americans leaving their cultural values eroded and the native language devastated. South Africa has eleven official languages - English being one of them and probably the most crucial in the fight against apartheid and the transition from the Afrikaner government to the ANC lead government. Black South Africans realised that English was a useful tool and medium for communication - it was a world language. The European Union has fifteen official languages which often creates problems for the translators during EU meetings. English has become the working language but there is also recognition that languages of identity need equal respect. Finally, a debate takes place in Kyoto, Japan, about the future and probable disappearance of many native languages. Narrated by Hugh Quarshie.

description_for_label: With the advent of the 21st century came the unstoppable global spread of English as the universal language. “Beyond Babel” explores the reasons behind this phenomenal growth through four separate programs: Trade, Culture, Politics, Future. In this third program the role of English is examined as a medium for international political and diplomatic discourse. Television news via satellite has created a global connection with English as the linking language. America’s CNN was the first global television broadcaster and it was their philosophy (initiated by Ted Turner), to de-Americanise the language to appeal to an international audience. Discusses British colonization of America, followed by the mainly non-English speaking immigrants who formed linguistic ghettos in New York, to today where there has been a dramatic increase in Hispanic immigrants speaking mainly Spanish. A reactionary organization known as “US English” with the slogan “English must be our official language” is gathering in strength to an extent where there are 25 American States who have passed “English only” legislation. Comment is also made about the demise of the Native Americans whose culture and language was deliberately destroyed by white Americans leaving their cultural values eroded and the native language devastated.
